Award.AwardTitle: Radiative Atomic Processes in Iron-Peak Elements For Non-LTE Astrophysical Models
Award.AbstractNarration: Dr. Nahar and her team compute large-scale, high precision transition and recombination probabilities, oscillator strengths, and photoionization cross-sections for the Fe-peak elements, Cr, Fe, Co, Ni and Zn in their first five low-ionization stages. Improved parameters for these elements are necessary for spectral line modeling in the non-thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) calculations used in quantitative stellar spectroscopy. The self-consistent integration of the radiation field with microscopic material properties in NLTE models is based on explicit treatment of coupled physical processes in the source. This requires an extensive set of atomic parameters for all levels contributing to spectral line formation with adequate precision. The overall accuracy of stellar spectra from NLTE calculations depends on approximations made in the NLTE formalism itself. This work improves the physical framework for NLTE stellar models that can use sufficiently large photon frequency grids now possible on supercomputing platforms. The computations use relativistic R-matrix codes in combination with a Breit-Pauli method and yield photoionization cross sections, radiative and dielectronic recombination rates, electron impact excitation rates, photoexcitation and radiative decay rates for the iron group atoms and ions. These parameters will improve understanding models and observations such as radiatively driven mass-loss, spectral "forests" or pseudo-continuum of millions of lines, and chemical evolution of the relative proportion of Fe-peak elements. This project trains a postdoctoral fellow in advanced theoretical and computational methods in atomic physics, plasma physics and astrophysics, and high-performance computing on massively parallel platforms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has been successful in exploring number of complex atomic systems,
understanding the observed phenomena in the spectrum caused by their interaction
with photons, and finding new features in the processes that can be used for our
advancement. Spectral lines are formed by several atomic processes, such as,
excitation either by photon absorption or by electron impact, de-excitation,
photoionization, and electron-ion recombination. The aim was to study all the
these processes and obtain extensive set of atomic parameters with adequate
precision for  all levels contributing to spectral formation. The quantitative
spectroscopic analysis requires non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE)
numerical models implementing these large sets of atomic parameters,

This NSF awarded project has resulted in  high-accuracy calculations for the
Fe-peak elements, such as, Fe, Ti and ions of lighter elements, such as,  O,
Ne, P. The atomic parameters considered include (i) energies, {ii) oscillator
strengths, line strengths and A-values for bound-bound transitions, (iii)
totla and partial photoionization cross sections for all excited fine
structure levels up to n = 10, (iv) level-specific and total electron-ion
recombination  rate coefficients and total recombination cross sections.
All atomic data have been made freely available on-line at the PI's database
website, named NORAD-Atomic-Data at : http://norad.astronomy.ohio-state.edu

Some exemplory outcomes are presented  below:
- New characteristic radiation absorption features of iron that impact the
radiation transfer (opacity) in the sun which is a standard to study stars
(Fig. 1). These explain less elemental abundances seen in Sandia experiment
and obtained by 3D astrophysical modeli (Fig. 2)
- Study of Ti photoionization process is needed for determination of the
emerging flux distribution in cool stars, such as red giants which is expected

o be the fate of our sun, where Ti I is  seen in their spectrum. The low energy
behavior of resonant absorption found in the study indicates lower flux as
speculated (Fig. 4).
- The first detailed study of features in phosphorus which is one basic element,
like carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, of evolution of life, It is responsible in DNA
network. However very limited investigations have been made on it. Phosphorus
is widely used in various every day applications.  P II, P III lines are now
being detected in astrophysical spectra. The newly found features in an
experiment were interpreted and indentified in the work (Fig.5).
- Significant applications of method and results  in other areas includes
proposed I) effective x-ray radiation therapy at resonant energy of the
radiosensitizing agents (e.g. for gold in Fig. 6), ii) set-up to  produce
monochromatic x-rays for imaging, diagnostics, and therapy, iii) providing
evidence that low energy x-rays of a few hundred keV range are more effective
than the high energy x-rays of MeV range and hence cut down the cost
considerably, iv) electrical discharge machining process in mechanical
engineering, etc.
- It may be noted that the capability of close-pouing approximation and R-matrix
method, employed in the project through use of super computers at Ohio
Supercomputer Center, to treat the atomic systems in ab initio manner were
the key to accuracy and production of large amount of atomic parameters.

The PI has trained several graduate students and researchers with the
calculations for their independent research projects. She has also been
promoting physics education and research in a number of developing countries,
